definition: to send out/to show (one's feeling)/to issue/to develop/to make a bundle of money/classifier for gunshots (rounds)
trouble/disturbance/rumpus/flirty/coquettish/abbr. for 離騷|离骚[Li2 Sao1]/literary writings/smell of urine/foul smell/male (animal) (dialect)

sentences.english: Her long hair is often plained.
This is the third time the tourists squawked about the service of the hotel.
sentences.chinese: 這是旅客們第三次對飯店的服務發牢騷了。

sentences.english: He is forever croaking about his problems .
sentences.chinese: 他老是爲他那些問題發牢騷。

sentences.english: Do you have the time, To listen to me whine.
sentences.chinese: 你有時間，來聽我發牢騷嗎。

sentences.english: You don’t like it here, don’t fuck so much next time.
sentences.chinese: 如果不喜歡這裏，就別他媽的在這裏發牢騷。

sentences.english: Go on, go on, ILove to hear you whine.
sentences.chinese: 繼續說啊，我喜歡聽你發牢騷。

sentences.english: I’m really bored with his sitting there doing nothing but beefing.
sentences.chinese: 他坐在那裏什麼事也不幹，總是發牢騷，真煩死人。

sentences.english: I wish he'd stop belly-aching about his children's behaviour.
sentences.chinese: 我希望他不要再爲孩子們的行爲發牢騷了。

sentences.english: Just under one third said grousing was intheFrench temperament.
sentences.chinese: 近三分之一的人說法國人愛發牢騷是性情使然。

sentences.english: It is beneath him to grumble.
Online to small demon grumble, from the manager to customer scold soundly sweat.
sentences.chinese: 在線上向小妖發牢騷，從經理到客戶罵得酣暢淋漓。

sentences.english: They say that some men are grouchy because they have a physical problem.
sentences.chinese: 他們發現有些人愛發牢騷是因爲身體上的毛病。

sentences.english: They are beginning to murmur against new taxes.
sentences.chinese: 他們開始對新徵的稅發牢騷。

sentences.english: Just under one third said grousing was in the French temperament.
sentences.chinese: 近三分之一的人說法國人愛發牢騷是性情使然。

sentences.english: Some people grumble said, if regularly rising, how does let the human live?
sentences.chinese: 有人發牢騷說，要是隔三岔五的漲，讓人怎麼活啊？

definition: to spend effort/to take trouble/May I trouble you to...? (as part of polite request)/Please would you mind...?
lit. if it's wrong, it's wrong (idiom); to make the best after a mistake/to accept an error and adapt to it/to muddle through
hard to explain in a few words (idiom); complicated and not easy to express succinctly
worse than a beast/to behave immorally
to resign oneself to adversity (idiom); to grin and bear it/to submit meekly to insults, maltreatment, humiliation etc
